chapter.summary: Describes when to refer a person to an allergy specialist following an insect bite or sting.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with an insect bite or sting?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Referral to an allergy specialist should be made (with urgency depending on clinical judgement) for people who have had, or are suspected of having, a systemic reaction to an insect bite or sting.
    • Advise people who have had a systemic reaction to an insect sting to consider carrying a medical identification bracelet or necklace.
    • People who have had a previous severe systemic reaction and have been supplied with an adrenaline auto-injector (AAI) should be aware that they should seek emergency medical attention if they need to use their AAI, as these are not a substitute for emergency medical attention.
  • Discuss with an allergy specialist (with urgency depending on clinical judgement) the need to refer people who:
    • Have had a large local reaction (area of oedema, erythema and pruritus more than 10 cm in diameter which peaks between 24 and 48 hours after the sting).
  • Seek advice from an allergy specialist regarding interim management of anyone waiting to be seen by the allergy clinic.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to refer a person to secondary care following an insect bite or sting are based on the clinical guidelines Stinging Insect Hypersensitivity: A Practice Parameter Update 2011 [Golden et al, 2011], Diagnosis and management of hymenoptera venom allergy: British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) guidelines [Krishna et al, 2011], Anaphylaxis: assessment and referral after emergency treatment  [NICE, 2011] and Anaphylaxis – a practice parameter update 2015, American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology (AAAAI) [Liberman et al, 2015], expert opinion in review articles [DTB, 2012; BMJ Best Practice, 2016] and a factsheet Insect Venom Allergy Factsheet [Anaphylaxis Campaign, 2015].

  • Patients who have had a systemic reaction to an insect sting should be referred to an allergy specialist for further investigation (such as skin testing or specific antibody testing), consideration of venom immunotherapy (VIT), education on avoidance of stings and self-administration of adrenaline [Golden et al, 2011; Krishna et al, 2011].
    • VIT is recommended for all people with a severe systemic reaction following a sting and in many after a moderate systemic reaction following a sting [Krishna et al, 2011].
    • People who have had a systemic reaction to an insect sting should consider carrying a medical identification bracelet or necklace [Golden et al, 2011].
  • Patients who have previously had large local reactions (LLR) often have LLRs to subsequent stings, and up to 10% might eventually have a systemic reaction [Golden et al, 2011].
    • People who have had a LLR or children who have had only mild cutaneous systemic reactions may not require venom testing or VIT. However, 5–10% of people experiencing LLRs are at risk of a future systemic reaction. The decision as to whether to prescribe auto-injectable adrenaline should be at the discretion of the allergy specialist [Golden et al, 2011].
